document.title: Syllabus Cambridge International AS & A Level Marine Science 9693

07428D6497CC40808BCD2B585E5A4041.description: discuss the threats to mangrove forests, including temperature change, over-harvesting, storm damage and change in coastal land use

80818C00D3DB4EADBF4505070AC54AAA.description: discuss the importance of mangrove forests, including tourism, food source, coastal protection, timber, fuel source and biodiversity

E79E386942CF47C29D1F0637E0AAB79F.description: sediment trapping which stabilises and protects the coastline and prevents sediment build up on coral reefs and seagrass beds

AE525840B1BF479DAA652544CC2F858A.description: nursery area for juveniles of many animal species

8FEAAFEF27474D8EBB7C2030E7BE0521.description: explain the ecological importance of mangrove forests in terms of:

6E744CF3490F4E82AFCBEF4991C31BF3.description: prop roots for stability in unstable substrates and supplementary oxygen uptake due to low oxygen concentrations in the substrate

04D4F76DF54D48A284EE4E083BAE49A0.description: explain how the red mangrove tree, Rhizophora mangle, shows adaptations to its environment, including:

1D9EB60351F74BB884C3859A08F60128.description: outline the conditions required for the formation of mangrove forest

E03F78A745504CAD941C5DBB7B72AA01.description: describe the mangrove forest as a tidal ecosystem featuring salt tolerant trees and other plants, together with populations of other species, all interacting in the littoral zone of some tropical and subtropical coasts

1D951FE6E14F4904A02185A5CD40B9B4.description:
The mangrove forest: Mangroves have adaptations for surviving in environments where they are partly submerged
in salt water. They grow on muddy shores in tropical and subtropical regions, and have a major influence on biodiversity. They are of great value to human coastal communities, although many human activities pose serious threats to mangrove forests.

597A7CABEAC94B94BDB7BE8166E7BF47.description: explain, using named examples, the adaptations that organisms have to living on a sandy shore

CEDD71DB3F4542188BD95450B8ED697D.description: (PA) investigate the effect of particle size on the permeability of substrates

A6ABA7DB40334E9D82BF0AC9C64C7E60.description: explain how the biotic and abiotic factors that affect a sandy shore lead to a relatively low biodiversity

AC8830B8C452464287DFD4222CFB2FBB.description: describe the sandy shore as an ecosystem with an unstable, shifting substrate that is porous

35C17AEFEFF642D3B7DF9D9F5FA65E4B.description:
The sandy shore: Organisms cannot attach securely to the unstable substrate on sandy shores. The variations in abiotic factors through the tidal cycle can be even greater than on a rocky shore, and relatively few types of organism have adaptations
� such as the ability to burrow � that enable them to live there.

27909468F91D4B3086FA0D34363C3CE1.description: explain, using named examples, the adaptations that organisms have to living in the different zones (for example the adaptations to prevent desiccation)

687F53231A414CCEBA5F321A76E57DA3.description: explain how biotic and abiotic factors interact to affect the distribution and abundance of organisms in the different zones on the rocky shore (candidates should study a range of named organisms from the different zones)

3C4B00E544C14B12BCEB0CC4008469D0.description: identify the different zones on a typical exposed rocky shore, limited to splash zone, upper shore, middle shore, lower shore and subtidal zone and describe the changing abiotic factors across these zones during one tidal cycle

09A599208DF74E44B3D08FFF1F9136F8.description:
The rocky shore: Organisms living on rocky shores experience variations in temperature and salinity, availability of water and
exposure to sunlight at different stages of the tidal cycle. High on the shore, these abiotic factors are the main influence on the distribution and abundance of species, but lower down the shore biotic factors such as competition and predation have the greatest influence.

59E35F18951B4F9EA458B347EBD49335.description: discuss the use of artificial reefs

733D3951372A4E249837908DE3576D9E.description: discuss the causes and effects of reef erosion, including pH change, temperature change, predation, physical damage and the presence of sediment

2EDF322B6FE74002A1D2CD2C0EAD795B.description: discuss the importance of coral reefs, including tourism, food source, coastal protection, medicines and biodiversity

97E005B643154894A441C908A088302D.description: explain how corals obtain their nutrition, including the mutualistic relationship between the polyps of some corals and zooxanthellae

BCB94296176448FEBB1AA7E18B26CD7E.description: describe the structure of a typical hard coral polyp, limited to tentacle, nematocyst, mouth, stomach, calyx, theca and basal plate, and describe the functions of these structures

BDD17080FFA94FAAB823B1E54FBA39B9.description: understand that the two general types of coral, hard (for example, staghorn) and soft (for example, sea fan) vary in the extent of calcification and population size of zooxanthellae

A5AC3878399B432D8B4679ED43801920.description: describe corals as animals in the phylum Cnidaria that form sessile colonies of polyps, often having a symbiotic relationship with zooxanthellae

9708F0A56D8C4F70B6282DF79B7DFB5D.description: describe and compare the four types of tropical coral reef: fringing, barrier, patch and atoll, in terms of their proximity to the coast and lagoon structure (if present)

73BB59A459E2436EBA58FF7A3FD6F966.description: describe the conditions required for tropical coral reef formation

5902357B522142FBA2F13B2DA19DCA0F.description:
The tropical coral reef
Tropical coral reefs are built by tiny coral polyps, which live in close association with photosynthetic zooxanthellae and are therefore limited in
their distribution to areas where abundant light is available
and temperatures are warm. The polyps themselves are consumers and require a source of small organisms that they can capture and digest.

Changes to biotic or abiotic factors in the oceans can lead to the erosion of coral reefs. Artificial structures can be provided as a substrate on which reef communities can develop.

5F98D1B9BD9A4159A55B344878BB4F46.description: identify regions of the oceans as polar, temperate, or tropical

E00455304A8D4F22B634CCE4821C1D62.description: explain the importance of oceans and their interaction with the atmosphere:

FB5DE8B6DFF8413C9F2A63B48852F3B9.description: identify zones found in the open ocean, limited to epipelagic, mesopelagic, bathypelagic, abyssopelagic and benthic zones, and describe these zones in terms of light penetration

CA8E7FAA5F7744A699B6FDE160C0C284.description: identify the world�s five oceans as the Arctic, Atlantic, Pacific, Indian and Southern, and understand that these oceans are inter-connected and encircle the Earth as a World Ocean

5D0F882863D04A9BBA6B9F393F208ABD.description:
The open ocean: Depth zones in the oceans range from the surface layers to the very deepest parts in the
benthic zones. The oceans have considerable influence on global climate and on the composition of the atmosphere, with which they continually interact.

AA6564CAB99C4BC488569E98F23E90E2.description:
use Spearman�s rank correlation (rs ) to analyse the relationships between the distribution and abundance of species and abiotic or biotic factors
(the equation and symbols for the calculation of rs will be provided in the question papers)

E29BCCDE3D5040849A3E463A1C2065D4.description:
use Simpson�s index of diversity (D) to calculate the species diversity of a habitat and interpret different values of D
(the equation and symbols for the calculation of D will be provided in the question papers)

364CD226640E4F7398E27FD81DC1C7D6.description: (PA) use suitable methods, including frame quadrats, line transects, belt transects and mark-release-recapture, to investigate the distribution and abundance of organisms in the littoral zone (note that candidates should be taught the importance of designing an ethical and safe method)

29EA4B1AE089418FA33120A9B6CD5125.description: describe random and systematic sampling and understand their advantages and disadvantages

E13941BB5EA3479F90E27FE9EC36A7C4.description: apply the Lincoln index and identify the limitations of this method (the equation and symbols for the Lincoln index will be provided in the question papers)

777F978945A849EDA4352C2E0B430B32.description: understand the mark�release�recapture method for estimating population size of a named species

DF824485506E405290906618AC9C4C61.description: explain the terms biotic factor (including intra- and inter-specific competition, symbioses, predation and disease) and abiotic factor (including salinity, temperature, pH, oxygen concentration, carbon dioxide concentration, light availability, turbidity, wave / tide action, nutrient availability and exposure to air) and identify those factors that affect an organism in a named marine ecosystem

56BF0B3015BE4B6491BE36B0F6F7EEF7.description: explain, using marine examples, the terms ecosystem, habitat, niche, species, population and community

49F58CB467A8477988B79D3452659725.description:
Populations and sampling techniques: Biotic and abiotic factors affect the distribution and abundance of different types of organism in the marine environment. It is important to select appropriate techniques to study distribution and abundance in particular circumstances � for example, whether sampling should be
random or systematic. The data collected can be analysed to look for correlations between abundance and a particular environmental factor.

A1CB03AA31DC44D6948026DA4D65969A.description: providing a source of medicines (for example, anticancer drugs such as keyhole limpet hemocyanin (KLH))

861955736568491F989CBCCA6BB32F83.description: providing food sources (for example, algae, crustaceans and fish)

9E9D4E9F40744BB48217EEBC4D78CC53.description: climate control (for example, phytoplankton absorb CO2 and release O2)

64423357C5594F75868A979E4D980C6E.description: protection of the physical environment (for example, coral reefs protect coastlines)

D788875B3F9245BDBCEAC0356A21B9FA.description: maintaining stable ecosystems (for example, diversity in communities maintains complex interactions between all organisms and the physical environment)

3644DCAE496A48E0B6C65BE38B44E521.description: understand the importance of marine biodiversity in terms of the services / benefits it provides, including:

64B86C846E6C4DBE87B171C0AF52A23A.description: ecological diversity (variation in ecosystems on a regional and global level)

D12EB235D7944A03A6CE737DE31B5BB2.description: species diversity (number of species and their relative abundance)

B9CE998D24C64E489FF55FA7B116F226.description: genetic diversity (variation in the genes of a species)

C85ECB8810A44FE993BE216FD2DE35CD.description: explain that biodiversity can be considered at three different levels:

FBCCC2FAF16F42469383F17FF4BC94C5.description: understand the ecological and economic importance of marine plants, including seagrass

A63EB54DF6D54F94AB1CF71BAC252669.description: state the main features of a typical marine plant, such as seagrass, including rhizome, roots, flowers and leaves

DDBD1500CEAA498F8678F1F5A534CB9D.description: understand the ecological and economic importance of macroalgae, including kelp

7894EBF4893C4D58A9881BA60E3F1C32.description: state the main features of a typical macroalga, such as kelp, including holdfast, stipe, gas bladders and blades

AC48882759F8482792F29C370F0FE0B7.description: understand that bony fish and cartilaginous fish are both chordates (i.e. in the phylum Chordata) and that all organisms in this phylum share common features (at some point in their development), including notochord, dorsal neural tube, pharyngeal slits and post-anal tail

36AC123CC29948AD976FFE80ABB16B5C.description: understand the ecological and economic importance of cartilaginous fish, including the blue shark

41E5AA28FF0446C595D76BE28B94F028.description: state the main internal and external features of a typical adult cartilaginous fish, including cartilaginous skeleton, gill slits, gills, denticles, lateral line, fins (pectoral, caudal, pelvic, anal and dorsal)

62A0458EF63D483186960963623F2566.description: understand the ecological and economic importance of bony fish, including the Peruvian anchoveta

A4830120DC58426A8EFC69DCC9B96837.description: state the main internal and external features of a typical adult bony fish, including bony skeleton, operculum, gills, swim bladder, scales, externally visible lateral line, fins (pectoral, caudal, pelvic, anal and dorsal)

57B78346A0DE428E89A2516164BD1218.description: understand the ecological and economic importance of crustaceans, including Antarctic krill

FECE5B3E88AC4241B3190CE8DD30B201.description: state the main features of a typical adult crustacean, including carapace, segmented abdomen, jointed legs and two pairs of antennae

2AF318627B44439BB6816F2702EDD163.description: understand the ecological and economic importance of echinoderms, including the crown of thorns starfish

915DE09915D141739580650A00047F01.description: state the main features of a typical adult echinoderm, limited to pentaradial symmetry and tube feet

900EC51E9C8F4ACEA6FCB6ECBBAB7A72.description: understand that zooplankton are consumers; examples include larvae, copepods and larger animals such as jellyfish

018F7BE10D62423B9E1F1DA5E43F6D6F.description: understand that phytoplankton are producers which absorb nutrients from their environment (like all producers) and obtain their nutrition by photosynthesis; examples include microscopic algae such as diatoms and dinoflagellates

397557740A4F47FDBB477EB9B84A1011.description: define plankton as a diverse collection of generally microscopic organisms that have limited motility and drift in water currents

1711BE8B68574E359B559770831BDE65.description:
Key groups of marine organisms: The number of phyla living in the oceans is considerably greater than on land. The adults and larvae of many different types of organism are planktonic, drifting in ocean currents. Crustaceans, echinoderms, bony fish and cartilaginous fish are some of the more obvious animals in
the oceans, while macroalgae (seaweeds) and seagrasses form the basis of many food chains.

E698FADFE5814B6ABA7F4C3C06D02C82.description: (PA) make observations and drawings from unfamiliar structures or specimens from the key groups in topic 4.2 and additionally Cnidaria in topic 5.2

A4A2333AC159417F92F09C5A4F9EBF09.description: construct and use simple dichotomous keys based on easily identifiable features

B90A2D89AC5F4616B9CDF9AB543C65CF.description: understand and use the binomial system of species nomenclature

71E2C41669D9473CA39343F7F28A5B58.description: describe the classification of species into the taxonomic hierarchy of domain, kingdom, phylum, class, order, family, genus and species

4488D0FB75954050BB7A24E11DCD5DFC.description:
The classification of marine organisms: Organisms are classified in a hierarchical system, in which the largest group is the domain. Each type of organism belongs to a particular species, which is given a universally recognised two-word name called a binomial. 

Dichotomous keys are made up of pairs of contrasting descriptions, constructed so 
that the sequential choice of one of each pair leads to the name of the organism.

D2A4B485784740D19E62026BCD479B3A.description: describe the carbon cycle, limited to combustion, photosynthesis, respiration, decomposition, formation of fossil fuels, formation and weathering of rocks containing carbonate ions

6E17EEB5A7814B748A9D8CC21D5BC6CF.description: explain why productivity may be limited by the availability of dissolved nutrients

B9AA4345A5EF47DF8EFABDCE9340AA2D.description: understand that the nutrients taken up by organisms in food chains can be removed by harvesting

19938CC2E5514AF6ABFF2750A2D55158.description: outline how marine snow transfers energy-containing organic material from surface waters to the deep ocean

4A0D9D730F1B48EC8017ECEE8C0C06EE.description: understand that the reservoir of dissolved nutrients is depleted by uptake into organisms

4105A0AAE042405899BDBE4DD2D1B5B4.description: explain the processes by which the reservoir of dissolved nutrients is replenished, including upwelling, run-off, tectonic activity, dissolving of atmospheric gases, excretion and decomposition

D6995110B1504FE28DACBBA72AF7E4D7.description: understand that some nutrients are soluble and that there is a reservoir of these nutrients dissolved in the ocean which is available to producers and consumers

12B45144430244D9974DB1E4D6F3ACDF.description: phosphorus, which is used to make DNA and bones

591829076F1546D794F4317E3D895BDF.description: calcium, which is used to make bones, shells and coral skeletons

8B5094A03EE845468B332848A9CE6C9A.description: magnesium, which is used to make chlorophyll

451B107664894D09B2CEF06E81342014.description: carbon, which is used to make all organic compounds

BC34FE62622D4051A4F54CAF9BEE70AB.description: nitrogen, which is used to make proteins, chlorophyll and DNA

4690D4E96643400096EB66B3B81D509C.description: understand that some nutrients supply organisms with a source of essential elements and these elements have important biological roles:

452EAE1A0F974F9A8CE13BD2D7A04AB2.description: state that large molecules are made from smaller molecules, limited to starch and cellulose from glucose, proteins from amino acids, and lipids from fatty acids and glycerol

2B9F2E43F207428CA2A59B2F0D428547.description: state the chemical elements that make up carbohydrates, lipids and proteins

B64EE818D3374B47BB5346CAF44FEB50.description: understand that nutrients can include gases such CO2, ions such as Mg2+, CO32�, PO43� and NO3� and organic compounds such as carbohydrates, lipids and proteins

6299B2EC478A4E7BA36E073EE109066C.description: understand that nutrient is a generic term for substances that are required by an organism for growth, repair, energy or normal metabolism

8B29DB74FA5244358C4EE6E9C86CB657.description:
Nutrient cycles: Nutrients are materials that are required by organisms for an energy supply, and for growth and maintenance of body tissues. The availability of nutrients has a large effect on productivity, and therefore on the types and numbers of
organisms that live in different parts of the oceans at different times.

E2AA5922A2E04668B40F9ED63667BE69.description: draw, describe and interpret pyramids of energy, numbers and biomass, including those that incorporate parasites and periods of plankton / algal bloom

996DFFA6694B48EAB7A4554374BD9518.description: calculate and explain the energy losses along food chains

A51CB1510BD24F7EABFBDA5C40D1016D.description: define productivity as the rate of production of biomass per unit area or volume per unit of time and explain how high primary productivity may influence food chains

8CB026E09F1A4FA8A1F5BC1AA9A50708.description: understand that some of the glucose produced by photosynthesis is used in respiration to provide usable energy and can be summarised by the word equation glucose + oxygen ??? carbon dioxide + water (further details of respiration and balanced chemical equations are not required at AS Level)

90F178ACAB6B4B7EAB5BDBDB44F8D6DD.description: understand that some of the glucose produced by photosynthesis is used to produce biomass

E38DABFA8B85407EA8FE3CE22E0C7620.description: (PA) investigate the effect of light intensity on the rate of photosynthesis (use of fresh water plants is acceptable)

AD20918F3FD5446E975E79668B35C937.description: explain that photosynthesis captures the energy of sunlight and makes some of the energy available to the food chain, and, it can be summarised by the word equation carbon dioxide + water ?li?ght? glucose + oxygen chlorophyll (further details of photosynthesis and balanced chemical equations are not required at AS Level)

BAFA1907F0F146CBB8448A6741E89396.description: understand that producers can be photosynthetic or chemosynthetic

49C27F6F7E1A42698FAEA5ACF2CE7C2A.description: represent and interpret feeding relationships in an ecosystem as food chains and food webs

6CA3770FAD03470AB0697F408D857026.description: explain the following terms in relation to feeding relationships: consumer (including primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary), producer, herbivore, carnivore, omnivore, decomposer, predator, prey, food chain, food web, trophic level

6337DD84D6744A789A5B68CC1E95D923.description:
Feeding relationships: Producers harness an energy source � through either photosynthesis or chemosynthesis � to convert
inorganic substances to organic substances, which contain energy that becomes available to consumers. The rate at which producers transfer energy
into organic substances and produce biomass is measured as productivity, and this is affected by factors such as the availability of light.

Energy is lost as it passes along a food chain, and this results
in a decrease in the energy content of the organisms at each trophic level.

A05DF366C03C493A90338FB9F11B55C2.description: describe mutualistic relationships, including the relationship between boxer crabs and anemones

383B0FE358414BC7B3979FADF7B320BB.description: describe commensal relationships, including the relationship between whales and barnacles

CA92D672575E4E35AC8D038DB2EFE8FE.description: describe parasitic relationships, including the relationship between copepods and marine fish

33308944465D47639B63A0DA250F5223.description: describe the meaning of parasitism, commensalism and mutualism, and understand that they are all examples of symbiotic relationships

8A25F41DCE4E41FE9D0B700876B66562.description: Interactions: Different species of organism may live in a close relationship with one another, which is known as symbiosis. Parasitism, commensalism and mutualism are types of symbiosis, differing from one another in the degree of benefit gained by the host and by the symbiont.

E718F9F3AB294677AB7755496DE9F850.description: discuss the causes and effects of El Ni�o and La Ni�a events during the El Ni�o Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle in the Pacific Ocean

3A0C7ABAF0B4414C94DDD601F1910D45.description: explain the formation of the global ocean conveyor belt and its importance in moving sea water around the Earth

B24F7C0DC9AA42D485FE32306C7C6308.description: describe how wind, temperature, density, the Coriolis effect (limited to the deflection of currents clockwise in the northern hemisphere and anticlockwise in the southern hemisphere) and the shape of the seabed produce ocean currents and upwelling

F11F147315F142B2A9547F38BB265F34.description: interpret tide tables and graphs in terms of tidal height, tidal range, spring and neap tides

C6BD86832DBC43F3BB19280B7F9C17EE.description: explain the formation of spring and neap tides

1EB0751BB88849D79556B4C7F54313AA.description: explain how tides are produced, and how the alignment of the Earth, Moon and Sun, coastal geomorphology, wind, air pressure and size of water body affect the tidal range

EF9BA321F29844E8A87AF0501299FD4B.description:
Tides and ocean currents: Twice each day, the level of the seas and oceans rises and
falls, in a pattern determined by the alignment of Earth, Moon and Sun. The magnitude of these changes in level, known as tides, is also affected by environmental factors such as winds.

Winds and temperature, along with other factors, also give rise to ocean currents. These currents ensure that the water in all the world�s oceans is able to mix, via the global ocean conveyor belt.

C875EA46B97A4D3F9C107A390E5DD9E8.description: describe how weathering, erosion and sedimentation give rise to the morphology of rocky shores, sandy shores, muddy shores, estuaries and deltas

86FABE00DDC349449C48113240CC9C58.description: state examples of the littoral zone, including rocky shores, sandy shores, muddy shores, estuaries and deltas

D377212A5FCA4FAEBB9F7CD865427B55.description: define the littoral zone as the intertidal region on a shoreline, between the highest and lowest spring tide marks

C3D6E37CD6E44F2499A88DDBFE2CBFB2.description: understand how the speed of water flow and particle size affect the removal, transport and deposition of particles

9BF1FEF7281D43BFA9F8DE6772CAF29F.description: describe sedimentation as the deposition of suspended particles

16F9108E5C4A465EB58CA94C787DEA6A.description: describe the four main types of erosion: by ice, water, wind and gravity

1FDADAB595FD442E8F5A56D86273986F.description: describe the three main types of weathering: chemical, physical and organic, and be able to describe an example of each type

89AC6D875EA64772B21EF39CAD631689.description:
Weathering, erosion and sedimentation: Weathering of rocks results in the production of small fragments, which may be eroded (carried away) and deposited elsewhere as
sediment. The balance between the rate at which sediments are eroded and deposited in the littoral zone determines the type of shore that forms.

803DF2E989014F399938341AAC34D307.description: explain how the chimneys form at hydrothermal vents, including reference to temperature and solubility of salts

DF869B8E8EC949C89DCC54BA89B4B8DF.description: understand that the effects of the hydrothermal vent plume can be detected some distance from the hydrothermal vent site

A9720DA9AD414E7D83876289BFFB7AB3.description: state that the water coming from hydrothermal vents is under pressure, hot and rich in dissolved nutrients and that this forms the hydrothermal vent plume

8D4DAA2AAA2E4E6E99B5093417F3A71C.description: explain how tectonic processes produce ocean trenches, mid- ocean ridges, hydrothermal vents, abyssal plains, volcanoes, earthquakes and tsunamis

3EDD9A6AE7524A35AFDA984038F850E8.description: identify and describe the three types of plate boundary as convergent, divergent and transform

05AAE146DDAC41398714F71645B73AB9.description: the jigsaw fit of the continental coastlines

A612F7641564420B84B79D88301E887E.description: paleomagnetic stripes on the ocean floor

69ED2CE4A5074DB2B955D31735F43102.description: distribution of similar fossils and living organisms on different continents

262FD67AEFB84F75B7D0C381E48A76F6.description: the geological matching of rock formations on different continents

79FBD8F851A940EF892CC7877CB9194F.description: describe and apply the theory of plate tectonics and the evidence supporting the theory limited to

65D55350E4984D8380AF18EB22FFB177.description: describe the structure of the Earth, limited to crust (oceanic and continental), mantle and core

C0E35D465AC149FBAF0DDEAFB3D7CCA3.description:
Tectonic processes: The movement of tectonic plates is responsible for the formation of many different features
of the ocean floor, including hydrothermal vents and ocean trenches, and phenomena such as earthquakes and tsunamis.

EEA5D4AA7F374F71863FB037134F2CF5.description: describe how temperature and salinity gradients form in water columns to produce ocean layers, including the surface layer, thermocline, halocline and deep ocean, and how subsequent mixing of these layers may occur

62B04FA7F61746CCB259DD71D382C3AE.description: explain the importance of ice floating, limited to its action as a thermal insulator and as a habitat for marine organisms

4B5CDF64B62D4733A4872133A5E1C17C.description: state that the density of ice is lower than sea water, causing ice to float

9D0D2DBAB427489F858E6D7E8F267546.description: recall and apply the formula: density = mass � volume, with units of kg m�3, kg and m3 respectively

0C25E86EC575432082FEB5E20CAE13B5.description: explain how water temperature, water pressure and salinity affect the density of sea water

54A1BB7A9F1D4EE4B938A9B669DCA50A.description:
Density and pressure: Density is a measure of the mass of a defined volume of water, and is affected by temperature, pressure and
salinity. Density differences help to maintain temperature and salinity gradients in the oceans, which affect the distribution of organisms.

6CCB6AB0F37446299EEDC33FF7B2E251.description: describe the effect of water temperature, water pressure (depth), atmospheric pressure and salinity on the solubility of gases in water and the implications this has for marine organisms (knowledge of the gas laws is not expected)

C593ED5EA7354619900C4EDAAF8B308D.description: state that oxygen has a low solubility in water

3D6C5B8EEE714F159815F4A71F032421.description: (PA) use litmus indicator to determine if a substance is acidic or alkaline or Universal Indicator and pH probes to measure the pH of water samples

E5E57D698A964316A1E5BA3F4F84D2D4.description: describe the pH scale as a measure of the hydrogen ion concentration in water, including the terms acidic, neutral and alkaline (calculations relating to hydrogen ion concentration are not required)

B462299C8D6248A4A5921E83EC0D7C3B.description: explain the effect of surface run-off, precipitation and evaporation on the salinity of sea water

9C27306A1E3F4869A38C1CBD44055834.description: (PA) investigate the effect of salinity on the freezing point of water

1B005E9DA007447C82246367619103D1.description: define the term salinity as the concentration of dissolved salts in sea water (note that the unit for salinity used in this syllabus is parts per thousand (ppt))

0498EB0C5F5B4300B7608D3429AC9610.description: explain the effect of water temperature on the solubility of salts

4A1A0B5D64824AA8AA1CF07D5E6B6C10.description: describe how soluble salts, such as sodium chloride, dissolve in water by the dissolution of ions

1899FB2B74F747A9B44FFF84AA64294A.description: explain the terms solute, solvent, solution and solubility

2B8BFC92E6C140C99CFA2E5D5E8B8C40.description: Solubility in water: Sea water is a solution made up of many different solutes dissolved in water. Various environmental factors affect the solubility of salts and gases in sea water. Hydrogen ion concentration is particularly important, as this affects pH.

72D354857C2A4950BE4E65118BF81529.description: explain how hydrogen bonding in water affects the properties of water, limited to solvent action, density, and specific heat capacity

E6132A31F8D84686A6F907A3DF0D905B.description: explain the formation of hydrogen bonds in water

884C6F3B32B44E12A4D2A9BE8BD52D9A.description: state the chemical name and formula of salts found in sea water, including sodium chloride (NaCl ), magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) and calcium carbonate (CaCO3)

955F73E6B774437090726492654D6CC8.description: identify (including from diagrams) ionic substances, including sodium chloride and calcium carbonate

5C1A97D82689412D8BD12FF40C3A8910.description: describe (including through the use of diagrams) the ionic bonding in sodium chloride, limited to the loss and gain of electrons to form ions and the subsequent attraction between positive and negative ions

F9A8BC31D0134C728C5CCA59E75D0386.description: identify (including from diagrams) covalent molecules, including water, carbon dioxide, oxygen, sulfur dioxide and glucose

E39CFE8E20CE4DD393F761A0F2B281EE.description: describe (including through the use of diagrams) the covalent bonding in a water molecule, limited to the sharing of electron pairs between atoms

BED4A0B36C7D40B2B083170D228A4761.description: understand that sea water is a mixture of different elements and compounds

2B1ED3E4E1F2459688E46DF583DA32EE.description: describe the structure of the atom, including the nucleus containing protons and neutrons, surrounded by electrons arranged in shells

FD4D82512C054AB9A4A64F8E41513869.description: explain the changes of state in water, between solid, liquid and gas, in terms of the kinetic particle theory

3465AE5E019E4E8CB702D96B029A269B.description:
Particle theory and bonding: An understanding of particle theory, including the structure of atoms and ions, and how they bond together to form
compounds, helps to explain the properties of water and other substances important to marine life.
